senses.definition: a piece of clothing worn on the top half of the body over a shirt, etc. that has arms and fastens down the front; a short, light coat

examples.x: a leather/denim/tweed jacket
I have to wear a jacket and tie to work.
a man in a black jacket and grey trousers

senses.definition: a loose paper cover for a book, usually with a design or picture on it
an outer cover around a hot water pipe, etc., for example to reduce loss of heat
the skin of a baked potato

examples.x: potatoes baked in their jackets

senses.definition: a stiff paper or thick card cover for a record
a prison

examples.x: She spent a year in jail.
He has been released from jail.
a ten-year jail sentence
Britain’s overcrowded jails

senses.definition: to put somebody in prison

examples.x: He was jailed for life for murder.

senses.definition: a thick sweet substance made by boiling fruit with sugar, often sold in jars and spread on bread

examples.x: strawberry jam
a jar/pot of jam
recipes for jams and preserves
a jam doughnut

senses.definition: a situation in which it is difficult or impossible to move because there are so many people or vehicles in one particular place

examples.x: The bus was delayed in a five-mile jam.
As fans rushed to leave, jams formed at all the exits.
We were stuck in a jam for an hour.

senses.definition: a situation in which a machine does not work because something is stuck in one position

examples.x: There's a paper jam in the photocopier.

senses.definition: used by the media to describe people who do not have much money to live on (the abbreviation for just about managing)

examples.x: JAMs may be in work, but are struggling to pay for essentials such as food, heating or rent.

senses.definition: to be in a difficult situation
good things that are promised for the future but never happen

examples.x: They refused to settle for a promise of jam tomorrow.

senses.definition: money that is earned very easily, for something that needs little effort

examples.x: The job only took about an hour—it was money for jam.

senses.definition: the 1st month of the year, between December and February

examples.x: She was born in January.
The meeting is on the fifth of January/January the fifth.
The meeting is on January fifth.
We went to Japan last January.
I arrived at the end of January.
last January's election
the January sales (= when a shop sells its goods at a lower price than usual)
It was a cold January morning.

senses.definition: a type of music with strong rhythms, in which the players often improvise (= make up the music as they are playing), originally created by African American musicians at the beginning of the 20th century

examples.x: traditional/modern jazz
a jazz band/club
jazz musicians
the rising stars of the New York jazz scene

senses.definition: and things like that

examples.x: How's it going? You know—love, life and all that jazz.

senses.definition: trousers made of denim (= a type of strong cotton)

examples.x: I always wear jeans.
a pair of designer jeans
skinny/baggy jeans
ripped/faded jeans
a young man in jeans and a T-shirt

senses.definition: a plane driven by jet engines

examples.x: a jet aircraft/fighter/airliner
The accident happened as the jet was about to take off.
He flew to Bermuda in his private jet.

senses.definition: a strong narrow stream of gas, liquid or flame that comes very quickly out of a small opening. The opening is also called a jet.

examples.x: The pipe burst and jets of water shot across the room.
to clean the gas jets on the cooker
Little jets of steam spurted from the engine.

senses.definition: a hard black mineral that can be polished and is used in jewellery

examples.x: jet beads

senses.definition: objects such as rings and necklaces that people wear as decoration

examples.x: silver/gold jewellery
She has some lovely pieces of jewellery.
I don't wear jewellery of any kind.
She inherited the family jewellery.
The nurse asked her to remove all her jewellery.
a jewellery shop
a jewelry store

senses.definition: work for which you receive regular payment

examples.x: I don't have a job at present.
He's trying to get a job.
I'm thinking of applying for a new job.
to look for/find a job
Did they offer you the job?
She took a job as a waitress.
She's just started a job with a travel company.
His brother's just lost his job.
to leave/quit your job
Don't be late again if you want to keep your job.
a temporary/permanent job
a summer/Saturday/holiday/vacation job
Both my parents have full-time jobs.
They're both in in part-time jobs.
She's never had a steady job (= a job that is not going to end suddenly).
It's one of the top jobs in management.
one of the people under consideration for the job of managing director
an increase in the number of people in jobs (= having jobs)
He's been out of a job (= unemployed) for six months now.
The takeover of the company is bound to mean more job losses.
There is so much competition in the job market currently.
He certainly knows his job (= is very good at his job).
I'm only doing my job (= I'm doing what I am paid to do).
These projects will help create jobs in rural areas.
The alternative would have been to cut jobs to contain costs.
The closure of the factory will mean the loss of over 800 jobs.

senses.definition: a particular task or piece of work that you have to do

examples.x: I've got various jobs around the house to do.
Sorting these papers out is going to be a long job.
The builder has a couple of jobs on at the moment.
She's taken on the job of organizing the Christmas party.

senses.definition: a responsibility or duty

examples.x: He said he wouldn't do it because it wasn't his job.
It's not my job to lock up!
It's the job of the press to expose wrongdoing.

senses.definition: a crime, especially stealing

examples.x: a bank job
He got six months for that last job he did.
an inside job (= done by somebody in the organization where the crime happens)
The gang bungled the job and got caught.

senses.definition: a particular kind of thing

examples.x: It's real wood—not one of those plastic jobs.

senses.definition: an item of work that is done by a computer as a single unit

examples.x: The job can be processed overnight.

senses.definition: not paying enough attention to what you need to do

examples.x: They were asleep on the job as the financial crisis deepened.
Let's hope the regulators are not asleep at the wheel.
Somebody must have been asleep at the switch to allow this to happen.

senses.definition: unemployed for a short time. People say ‘between jobs’ to avoid saying ‘unemployed’.

examples.x: He's between jobs at the moment so he's using the time to do some voluntary work.

senses.definition: a very difficult or unpleasant job or time

examples.x: I've had a devil of a job finding you.

senses.definition: to do something well, badly, etc.

examples.x: They did a very professional job.
You've certainly made an excellent job of the kitchen (= for example, painting it).
We haven’t done a very good job on the publicity for the show.

senses.definition: to be effective or successful in doing what you want

examples.x: This extra strong glue should do the job.
Try wedging it open—that should do the job.

senses.definition: to cause somebody/yourself to lose their/your job because the role is no longer required

examples.x: Our aim as a charity is to help people so successfully that we do ourselves out of a job.

senses.definition: to decide to stop trying to help somebody or to do something because there is no hope of success
used to tell somebody that they have done well at something
used to say that you are pleased about a situation or that somebody is lucky that something happened

examples.x: It's a good job you were there to help.

senses.definition: to have difficulty doing something

examples.x: You'll have a job convincing them that you're right.
He had a hard job to make himself heard.

senses.definition: work that you are paid to do or that must be done

examples.x: There was a job of work waiting for him that he was not looking forward to.

senses.definition: people use the expression jobs for the boys when they are criticizing the fact that somebody in power has given work to friends or relatives
exactly what is needed in a particular situation

examples.x: That cup of tea was just the job.

senses.definition: to accept a bad or difficult situation and do as well as you can
not worth doing because it is against the rules or because it might cause you to lose your job

examples.x: It's more than my job's worth to let you in without a ticket.

senses.definition: while doing a particular job

examples.x: No sleeping on the job!
on-the-job training

senses.definition: having sex
to stop working in order to go on strike
to fix or connect two or more things together

examples.x: Join one section of pipe to the next.
The island is joined to the mainland by a bridge.
The head was not joined onto the body.
A central hallway joins the two halves of the house.
Join the two sections of pipe together.
Draw a line joining (up) all the crosses.
How do these two pieces join?

senses.definition: if two things or groups join, or if one thing or group joins another, they come together to form one thing or group

examples.x: the place where the two paths join
The path joins the road near the trees.
Farmers can join together to get better prices.
They have joined with six other groups to lobby the government to end child poverty.

senses.definition: to become a member of an organization, a company, a club, etc.

examples.x: I've joined an aerobics class.
to join a group/club/team/party
She joined the company three months ago.
He left school to join the army.
to join the ranks of the unemployed
New members can join online.
It costs £20 to join.

senses.definition: to take part in something that somebody else is doing or to go somewhere with them

examples.x: Do you mind if I join you?
Will you join us for lunch?
They've invited us to join them on their yacht.
He joined her downstairs a few minutes later.
Over 200 members of staff joined the strike.
Members of the public joined the search for the missing boy.
I'm sure you'll all join me in wishing Ted and Laura a very happy marriage.

senses.definition: if you join a train, plane, etc. you get on it
if you join a road or a line of people, you start to travel along it, or move into it
if you cannot defeat somebody or be as successful as they are, then it is more sensible to join them in what they are doing and perhaps get some advantage for yourself by doing so
to begin fighting somebody

examples.x: The two armies joined battle.
Local residents have joined battle with the council over the lack of parking facilities.

senses.definition: used when something bad that has happened to somebody else has also happened to you

examples.x: So you didn't get a job either? Join the club!

senses.definition: to work together in order to achieve a shared aim

examples.x: The two firms joined forces to win the contract.
The two companies have joined forces to form a new consortium.

senses.definition: if two people join hands, they hold each other’s hands
to work together in doing something

examples.x: Education has been reluctant to join hands with business.

senses.definition: involving two or more people together

examples.x: a joint account (= a bank account in the name of more than one person, for example shared by a couple)
The report was a joint effort (= we worked on it together).
They finished in joint first place.
They were joint owners of the house (= they owned it together).

senses.definition: a place where two bones are joined together in the body in a way that enables them to bend and move

examples.x: inflammation of the knee joint
My joints are really stiff this morning.

senses.definition: a place where two or more parts of an object are joined together, especially to form a corner

examples.x: a joint between two lengths of copper

senses.definition: a piece of roast meat

examples.x: a joint of beef
the Sunday joint (= one traditionally eaten on a Sunday)

senses.definition: a place where people meet to eat, drink, dance, etc., especially one that is cheap

examples.x: a fast-food joint
The joint was jumping (= full of people and activity).

senses.definition: a cigarette containing marijuana (= an illegal drug)
to look carefully around a building in order to plan how to steal things from it at a later time
pushed out of its correct position

examples.x: She put her hip out of joint in the accident.

senses.definition: not working or behaving in the normal way

examples.x: Time is thrown completely out of joint in the opening chapters.

senses.definition: to upset or annoy somebody, especially by not giving them enough attention
something that you say or do to make people laugh, for example a funny story that you tell

examples.x: I can't tell jokes.
She's always cracking jokes.
They often make jokes at each other's expense.
The kids in that class are always looking to play a joke on the teacher.
I didn't get the joke (= understand it).
I wish he wouldn't tell dirty jokes (= about sex).
a sick joke (= about death, disease, etc.)
I only did it as a joke (= it was not meant seriously).
Have you heard the joke about the elephant and the mouse?

senses.definition: a person, thing or situation that is silly or annoying and cannot be taken seriously

examples.x: This latest pay offer is a joke.
This can't really be happening—it must be some kind of cruel joke.

senses.definition: to become annoying and no longer acceptable

examples.x: His teasing is getting beyond a joke.

senses.definition: to be difficult or unpleasant

examples.x: It's no joke trying to find a job these days.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody who tried to make another person look silly now looks silly instead

examples.x: I thought I'd play a trick on them, but in the end the joke was on me.

senses.definition: to laugh about something that is serious or should be taken seriously

examples.x: We tried to make a joke of our situation, but it wasn't really funny.

senses.definition: to be able to laugh at a joke against yourself

examples.x: The trouble with her is she can't take a joke.

senses.definition: to say something to make people laugh; to tell a funny story

examples.x: She was laughing and joking with the children.
I'm the sort of person who likes to joke a lot.
They often joked about all the things that could go wrong.
‘I cooked it myself, so be careful!’ he joked.

senses.definition: to say something that is not true because you think it is funny

examples.x: I didn't mean that—I was only joking.
We joked about the possibility of him buying out the company.
He was only half joking about being president one day.
She joked that she only loved him for his money.

senses.definition: used to show that you are now being serious after you have said something funny
used to show that you are very surprised at what somebody has just said

examples.x: She's going out with Dan? You're joking!
No way am I doing that. You must be joking!

senses.definition: a newspaper or magazine that deals with a particular subject or profession

examples.x: a scientific/an academic journal
the British Medical Journal
the Journal of Experimental Psychology
a trade/professional/specialist journal
an online journal
a journal article
The results of the study are expected to be published in a peer-reviewed journal next month.

senses.definition: used in the title of some newspapers

examples.x: the Wall Street Journal

senses.definition: a written record of the things you do, see, etc. every day

examples.x: He kept a journal of his travels across Asia.
I'm keeping a food journal for a school science project.
Her journal entry for that day describes a thunderstorm.

senses.definition: the work of collecting and writing news stories for newspapers, magazines, radio, television or online news sites; the news stories that are written

examples.x: I'd like a career in journalism.
This story was a good piece of investigative journalism.

senses.definition: a person whose job is to collect and write news stories for newspapers, magazines, radio, television or online news sites

examples.x: a freelance journalist
She's an investigative journalist with a French newspaper.
The minister told journalists he was not going to resign.

senses.definition: an act of travelling from one place to another, especially when they are far apart

examples.x: They went on a long train journey across India.
to begin/continue/complete a journey
Many refugees made the journey alone.
Did you have a good journey?
the outward/return journey
We broke our journey (= stopped for a short time) in Madrid.
Don't use the car for short journeys.
It's a day's journey by car.
The average journey time is about 50 minutes.
She took her sister with her to keep her company on the journey.
Devizes is a two-hour journey from London.
It is unclear why he embarked on his final journey to Vienna.
I'm afraid you've had a wasted journey (= you cannot do what you have come to do).
Bye! Safe journey! (= used when somebody is beginning a journey)

senses.definition: a long and often difficult process of personal change and development

examples.x: I was excited by the character's journey in the film.
The book describes a spiritual journey from despair to happiness.

senses.definition: a feeling of great happiness

examples.x: Her books have brought joy to millions.
the joy of discovery
the sheer joy of being with her again
I almost wept with joy.
I didn't expect them to jump for joy at the news (= to be very pleased).
I danced for joy when I found out I was pregnant.
Tears of joy were running down his cheeks.
To his great joy, she accepted.
He spoke of his joy at the news.
her joy at scoring the winning goal
Their joy in life and enthusiasm for learning are infectious.
Her joy in playing the violin was obvious.

senses.definition: a person or thing that causes you to feel very happy

examples.x: the joys of fatherhood
The game was a joy to watch.

senses.definition: success or satisfaction

examples.x: We complained about our rooms but got no joy from the manager.
‘Any joy at the shops?’ ‘No, they didn't have what I wanted.’

senses.definition: very cheerful
a person or thing that causes somebody to feel very pleased or satisfied

examples.x: The car is her pride and joy.
He loves that boat—it's his pride and joy.

senses.definition: a person in a court who has the authority to decide how criminals should be punished or to make legal decisions

examples.x: a High Court judge
a federal/district judge
the presiding trial judge
to appoint a judge
The case comes before Judge Cooper next week.
She will appear before a judge tomorrow.
The judge sentenced him to five years in prison.
The judge ruled that the evidence was inadmissible.

senses.definition: a person who decides who has won a competition

examples.x: The judges' decision is final.
She has joined the panel of judges in the popular TV talent show.
He was invited to be a judge in a cookery competition.

senses.definition: a person who has the necessary knowledge or skills to give their opinion about the value or quality of somebody/something

examples.x: She's a good judge of character.
He was a shrewd judge of people.
The last singer was the best—not that I'm any judge (= I do not know much about the subject).
‘I'm not sure that's a good way to do it.’ ‘Let me be the judge of that.’

senses.definition: to form an opinion about somebody/something, based on the information you have

examples.x: As far as I can judge, all of them are to blame.
Judging by her last email, they are having a wonderful time.
To judge from what he said, he was very disappointed.
You shouldn't judge her too harshly.
Schools should not be judged only on exam results.
Each painting must be judged on its own merits.
The tour was judged a great success.
The concert was judged to have been a great success.
They judged it wise to say nothing.
He judged that the risk was too great.
It was judged that the risk was too great.
It was hard to judge how great the risk was.

senses.definition: to guess the size, amount, etc. of something

examples.x: Young children are unable to judge the speed of traffic.
It's difficult to judge how long the journey will take.
I judged him to be about 50.

senses.definition: to decide the result of a competition; to be the judge in a competition

examples.x: She was asked to judge the essay competition.
The first team to cross the line will be judged the winner.
Their garden was judged the best in Wales by a TV viewers' poll.

senses.definition: to give your opinion about somebody, especially when you think they are bad

examples.x: What gives you the right to judge other people?
I'm not one to judge, but that's no way to behave.

senses.definition: to decide whether somebody is guilty or innocent in a court

examples.x: to judge a case
to judge somebody guilty/not guilty

senses.definition: used to say that you should not form an opinion about somebody/something from their appearance only
the ability to make sensible decisions after carefully considering the best thing to do

examples.x: good/poor/sound judgement
She showed a lack of judgement when she gave Mark the job.
It's not something I can give you rules for—you'll have to use your judgement.
He achieved his aim more by luck than judgement.
The accident was caused by an error of judgement on the part of the pilot.

senses.definition: an opinion that you form about something after thinking about it carefully; the act of making this opinion known to others

examples.x: In his portrait of the dictator he avoids any moral judgements.
Judgements of quality are always subjective.
He refused to make a judgement about the situation.
Who am I to pass judgement on her behaviour? (= to criticize it)
It will probably take some time for history to give its final judgement on his legacy.
It was, in her judgement, the wrong thing to do.
I did it against my better judgement (= although I thought it was perhaps the wrong thing to do).

senses.definition: the decision of a court or a judge

examples.x: a judgment from the European Court of Justice
The judgment will be given tomorrow.
The court has yet to pass judgment (= say what its decision is) in this case.

senses.definition: something bad that happens to somebody that is thought to be a punishment from God
to not decide or make a judgement about something until a later time

examples.x: I'd prefer to reserve judgement until I know all the facts.
Three judges have decided to reserve their decision until a later date.

senses.definition: to decide whether somebody’s behaviour is right or wrong, especially when you have no right to do this

examples.x: How dare you sit in judgement on me?

senses.definition: connected with a court, a judge or legal judgement

examples.x: judicial powers
the judicial process/system
Greenpeace applied for a judicial review to challenge the court’s decision.
The Supreme Court ordered a judicial inquiry into the deaths.

senses.definition: the liquid that comes from fruit or vegetables; a drink made from this

examples.x: a glass of fruit juice
a carton of apple juice
lemon/lime juice
Add the juice of two lemons.
Two orange juices, please.

senses.definition: the liquid that comes out of a piece of meat when it is cooked

examples.x: Use the juices of the meat to make gravy.

senses.definition: the liquid in the stomach that helps you to digest food

examples.x: digestive/gastric juices

senses.definition: electrical energy

examples.x: My phone has run out of juice.

senses.definition: petrol
power to influence people or influence what happens

examples.x: She has a lot of juice with city hall.

senses.definition: alcoholic drink

examples.x: He had been on the juice all weekend and was in a bad way.

senses.definition: anabolic steroids (= chemical substances taken by people to increase the size of their muscles)
a liquid containing nicotine that is used in a device for vaping

examples.x: The shelves are now full of vape pens and juices.
He needed some juice for his vape.

senses.definition: to leave somebody to worry and suffer the unpleasant effects of their own actions
the 7th month of the year, between June and August

examples.x: She was born in July.
The meeting is on the fifth of July/July the fifth.
The meeting is on July fifth.
We went to Japan last July.
I arrived at the end of July.
last July's election
It was a sunny July afternoon.

senses.definition: an act of jumping

examples.x: to do a parachute jump
a jump of over six metres
Somehow he survived the jump from the third floor of the building.

senses.definition: a barrier like a narrow fence that a horse or a runner has to jump over in a race or competition

examples.x: The horse fell at the last jump.

senses.definition: a sudden increase in amount, price or value

examples.x: unusually large price jumps
a 20 per cent jump in pre-tax profits

senses.definition: a large or sudden change

examples.x: Is he good enough to make the jump into Formula One?
The story takes a jump back in time.
The negotiations took a jump forward yesterday (= they made progress).
The new law is a jump into the unknown.

senses.definition: a sudden movement caused by shock or surprise

examples.x: I sat up with a jump.
Her heart gave a little jump at his smile.

senses.definition: to be going to be severely punished

examples.x: If I catch you cheating, you’ll be for the high jump.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody in a rude way to go away

examples.x: Why didn’t you just tell him to take a running jump?

senses.definition: to keep your advantage over somebody, especially your competitors, by taking action before they do or by making sure you know more than they do
to move quickly off the ground or away from a surface by pushing yourself with your legs and feet

examples.x: ‘Quick, jump!’ he shouted.
She jumped into the water to save them.
He jumped into the air and started cheering.
She jumped down from the chair.
The children were jumping up and down with excitement.
The pilot jumped from the burning plane (= with a parachute).
He killed himself by jumping off a bridge.
She has jumped 2.2 metres.

senses.definition: to pass over something by jumping

examples.x: He jumped over the wall to get away.
Can you jump that gate?
He jumped the stream and carried on up the hill.
His horse fell as it jumped the last hurdle.
I jumped my horse over all the fences.

senses.definition: to move quickly and suddenly

examples.x: He jumped to his feet when they called his name.
She jumped up and ran out of the room.
Do you want a ride? Jump in.
He jumped out of the car and disappeared into the building.
When she heard the news, she immediately jumped on a plane to France.

senses.definition: to make a sudden movement because of surprise, fear or excitement

examples.x: A loud bang made me jump.
Her heart jumped when she heard the news.

senses.definition: to rise suddenly by a large amount

examples.x: Prices jumped by 60% last year.
Sales jumped from $2.7 billion to $3.5 billion.
Your interest rate might suddenly jump at the end of the fixed period.
The FTSE 100 benchmark index jumped 199.9 points.

senses.definition: to change suddenly from one subject to another

examples.x: I couldn't follow the talk because he kept jumping about from one topic to another.
The story then jumps from her childhood in New York to her first visit to London.

senses.definition: to leave out something and pass to a further point or stage

examples.x: You seem to have jumped several steps in the argument.

senses.definition: to move suddenly and unexpectedly, especially out of the correct position

examples.x: The needle jumped across the dial.

senses.definition: to attack somebody suddenly

examples.x: The thieves jumped him in a dark alleyway.

senses.definition: to get on a vehicle very quickly, especially in a way that is dangerous or illegal

examples.x: to jump a train

senses.definition: to start the engine of a car by connecting the battery to the battery of another car with jump leads
to put a lot of energy into starting a process or an activity or into making it start more quickly
to be very lively

examples.x: The club's jumping tonight.

senses.definition: to be very angry or excited about something

examples.x: The local residents are jumping up and down complaining about the noise.

senses.definition: to join others in doing something that is becoming fashionable because you hope to become popular or successful yourself

examples.x: politicians eager to jump on the environmental bandwagon

senses.definition: to fail to appear at your trial after you have paid money to be allowed to go free until the trial

examples.x: He skipped bail and went on the run for two weeks.

senses.definition: to start or be made to start a new and difficult activity that you are not prepared for

examples.x: Junior hospital doctors are thrown in at the deep end in their first jobs.
The company believes in throwing new employees in at the deep end with no training.

senses.definition: to react very angrily to somebody
to do something too soon, before the right time
to fail to stop at a red traffic light
to move violently because of a sudden shock

examples.x: She nearly jumped out of her skin when she saw me.

senses.definition: to go to the front of a line of people without waiting for your turn

examples.x: She jumped the queue at the ticket counter.
Because he had money, he was able to jump the queue and get treatment that was not available to other people.

senses.definition: to leave the track suddenly
(used especially about a television series, etc.) to include something that is very hard to believe as an attempt to keep people watching, usually a sign that the show is not as good as it used to be

examples.x: Has the show finally jumped the shark?

senses.definition: to leave the ship on which you are serving, without permission
to leave an organization that you belong to, suddenly and unexpectedly
to do something difficult or complicated in order to achieve something

examples.x: You have to jump through so many hoops to get a job like this.

senses.definition: to make a decision about somebody/something too quickly, before you know or have thought about all the facts

examples.x: There I go again—jumping to conclusions.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to hurry and do something quickly
the place where two or more roads or railway lines meet

examples.x: It was near the junction of City Road and Old Street.
Come off the motorway at junction 6.
The most complicated motorway interchange in Britain is known as Spaghetti Junction.
In the 19th century the town became an important railway junction.

senses.definition: a place where two or more cables, rivers or other things meet or are joined

examples.x: a telephone junction box
the junction between nerves and muscles

senses.definition: the 6th month of the year, between May and July

examples.x: She was born in June.
The meeting is on the fifth of June/June the fifth.
The meeting is on June fifth.
We went to Japan last June.
I arrived at the end of June.
last June's election
the June edition of the newsletter

senses.definition: a first name for girls
having a low rank in an organization or a profession

examples.x: a junior partner/minister/officer
She is junior to me.

senses.definition: connected with young people below a particular age, rather than with adults, especially in sports

examples.x: He's a member of the club's junior team.
the world junior tennis championships

senses.definition: (especially in the US) used after the name of a man who has the same name as his father, to make it clear who is being referred to
for children under the age of 11 or 13

examples.x: the junior section of the school

senses.definition: connected with the year before the last year in a high school or college

examples.x: I spent my junior year in France.

senses.definition: the authority that an official organization has to make legal decisions about somebody/something

examples.x: The English court had no jurisdiction over the defendants.
The Court of Appeal exercised its jurisdiction to order a review of the case.
These matters do not fall within our jurisdiction.

senses.definition: an area or a country in which a particular system of laws has authority

examples.x: Practice varies between different European jurisdictions.

senses.definition: a group of members of the public who listen to the facts of a case in a court and decide whether or not somebody is guilty of a crime, or whether a claim has been proved

examples.x: members of the jury
The jury has/have returned a verdict of guilty.
to be/sit/serve on a jury
the right to trial by jury

senses.definition: a group of people who decide who is the winner of a competition

examples.x: He was on the jury for this year's Booker Prize.

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is still not certain

examples.x: The jury is still out on whether this is a good idea or not.

senses.definition: that most people consider to be morally fair and reasonable

examples.x: a just decision/law/society

senses.definition: people who are just
appropriate in a particular situation

examples.x: a just reward/punishment
I think she got her just deserts (= what she deserved).
They're campaigning for a just settlement.

senses.definition: only

examples.x: There is just one method that might work.
I decided to learn Japanese just for fun.
I waited an hour just to see you.
‘Can I help you?’ ‘No thanks, I'm just looking.’ (= in a shop)

senses.definition: simply

examples.x: It was just an ordinary day.
I just want to help.
I just think you should wait a bit.
We'll just have to hope for the best.
I'm just saying there are risks involved.
I'm just glad you're OK.
That's just plain stupid.
I can't just drop all my commitments.
This essay is just not good enough.
I didn't mean to upset you. It's just that I had to tell somebody.
This is not just another disaster movie—it's a masterpiece.
It has to be green—and not just any green, but a very precise shade of olive.
Just because you're older than me doesn't mean you know everything.
It just kind of happened.
If she doesn't like, that's just too bad.
I'm just so sick of this.
They just never give up.

senses.definition: by a small amount

examples.x: You've just missed her.
They just made it, boarding the aircraft minutes before take-off.
I only just caught the train.
Inflation fell to just over 4 per cent.
The painting sold for just under £6 million.
I got here just after nine.
They must have got there just before I did.
He visited Guatemala just prior to his death.
They're now the largest party, through just short of an overall majority.

senses.definition: used to say that you/somebody did something or something happened very recently

examples.x: I've just heard the news.
When you arrived, he had only just left.
She has just been telling us about her trip to Rome.
I just saw him a moment ago.
She was just here.
Just last week it was snowing and now it's 25 degrees.

senses.definition: at this/that moment; now

examples.x: I'm just finishing my book.
I was just beginning to enjoy myself when we had to leave.
I'm just off (= I am leaving now).

senses.definition: exactly

examples.x: This jacket is just my size.
With him, everything always has to be just right.
This gadget is just the thing for getting those nails out.
Just my luck (= the sort of bad luck I usually have). My phone needs recharging.
You're just in time.
She looks just like her mother.
It's just what I wanted!
It's just as I thought.
It's just on six (= exactly six o'clock).

senses.definition: at the same moment as

examples.x: The clock struck six just as I arrived.

senses.definition: no less than; equally

examples.x: She's just as smart as her sister.
You can get there just as cheaply by plane.

senses.definition: going to do something only a few moments from now or then

examples.x: The water's just about to boil.
I was just going to tell you when you interrupted.

senses.definition: really; completely

examples.x: The food was just wonderful!
The trip was just amazing!
Relax—you're doing just fine.
I can just imagine his reaction.

senses.definition: used in orders to get somebody’s attention, give permission, etc.

examples.x: Just listen to what I'm saying, will you!
Just help yourselves.

senses.definition: used to make a polite request, excuse, etc.

examples.x: Could you just help me with this box, please?
I've just got a few things to do first.

senses.definition: used to show a slight possibility that something is true or will happen

examples.x: Try asking Mike—he might just know the answer.

senses.definition: used to agree with somebody

examples.x: ‘He's very pompous.’ ‘Isn't he just?’

senses.definition: used to say that you/somebody would have been in the same position if you had done something else, because you got little benefit or pleasure from what you did do

examples.x: The weather was so bad we might just as well have stayed at home.

senses.definition: because of the possibility of something happening

examples.x: You'd better take the keys in case I'm out.
You probably won't need to call—but take my number, just in case.
In case (= if it is true that) you’re wondering why Jo’s here—let me explain…

senses.definition: it is a good thing

examples.x: It is just as well that we didn't leave any later or we'd have missed him.

senses.definition: used to say that you would equally well like to do something as do something else that has been suggested

examples.x: I'd just as soon stay at home as go out tonight.

senses.definition: almost; very nearly

examples.x: I've met just about everyone.
‘Did you reach your sales target?’ ‘Just about.’

senses.definition: approximately

examples.x: She should be arriving just about now.

senses.definition: suddenly, without warning or explanation
used to ask somebody to wait for a short time

examples.x: ‘Is Mr Burns available?’ ‘Just a second, please—I'll check.’

senses.definition: at this moment

examples.x: Come and see me later—I'm busy just now.

senses.definition: during this present period

examples.x: Business is good just now.

senses.definition: only a short time ago

examples.x: I saw her just now.

senses.definition: later; in a short period of time
done or arranged very accurately or carefully

examples.x: He liked polishing the furniture and making everything just so.

senses.definition: at that moment

examples.x: Just then, someone knocked at the front door.

senses.definition: exactly what is needed in a particular situation

examples.x: That cup of tea was just the ticket.

senses.definition: used when commenting on a situation to suggest that you could say something more or worse but prefer not to

examples.x: Let's just say he wasn't very happy about the decision (= he was very unhappy or angry about it).

senses.definition: not now but probably quite soon

examples.x: I can't give you the money just yet.

senses.definition: the fair treatment of people

examples.x: He pledged to seek justice for the victims of the tragedy.
Children often have a highly developed sense of justice.
laws based on the principles of natural justice

senses.definition: the quality of being fair or reasonable

examples.x: Who can deny the justice of their cause?
He demanded, not without justice, that he should be allowed to express his views.

senses.definition: the legal system used to punish people who have committed crimes

examples.x: the criminal justice system
The European Court of Justice
the administration/obstruction of justice
They were accused of attempting to pervert the course of justice.
They were accused of attempting to obstruct justice.

senses.definition: a judge in a court (also used before the name of a judge)
used before the name of a judge in a court of appeal

examples.x: Mr Justice Davies

senses.definition: to arrest somebody for a crime and put them on trial in court
to treat or represent somebody/something fairly, especially in a way that shows how good, attractive, etc. they are

examples.x: That photo doesn't do you justice.
He didn’t play as well as he can, but to do him justice, it was his first game since his injury.
The review did not do justice to her talents.

senses.definition: to deal with somebody/something correctly and completely

examples.x: You cannot do justice to such a complex situation in just a few pages.
I didn’t feel well and wasn’t able to do justice to the meal she had cooked (= I could not eat all the food).

senses.definition: to do something as well as you can in order to show other people how good you are

examples.x: She didn't do herself justice in the exam.

senses.definition: to tell a lie or to do something in order to prevent the police, etc. from finding out the truth about a crime
a good reason why something exists or is done

examples.x: I can see no possible justification for increasing taxes any further.
I could find no real justification for the proposed reorganization.
He was getting angry—and with some justification.
She was arrested entirely without justification.

senses.definition: as an explanation of why something exists or why somebody has done something

examples.x: All I can say in justification of her actions is that she was under a lot of pressure at work.
the argument which he put forward in justification

senses.definition: to show that somebody/something is right or reasonable

examples.x: How can they justify paying such huge salaries?
The results of the inquiry did not justify them departing from their existing policy.
Her success had justified the faith her teachers had put in her.

senses.definition: to give an explanation or excuse for something or for doing something

examples.x: The senator made an attempt to justify his actions.
The Prime Minister has been asked to justify the decision to Parliament.
You don't need to justify yourself to me.
He sought to justify taking these measures by citing the threat of a terrorist attack.
The press release was intended to justify them sacking her.

senses.definition: to arrange lines of printed text so that one or both edges are straight
bad or unfair methods of doing something are acceptable if the result of that action is good or positive

examples.x: He defended a morality in which the end justifies the means.
That's only OK if you believe that the end justifies the means.
